claim:
Consider the following background information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. Imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The right main coronary artery is most likely occluded in this patient.

supporting.text: The right coronary artery (RCA) supplies blood to the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, which is the area affected in this patient's transmural myocardial infarction.

attacks.text: The right coronary artery (RCA) supplies blood to the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, which is the area affected in this patient's transmural myocardial infarction.
In some individuals, the left circumflex artery (LCx) may supply the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, making RCA occlusion less likely.
Coronary artery dominance (right vs. left) must be confirmed via angiography before concluding RCA involvement, as anatomical variations exist.
The patient's symptoms (diaphoresis, nausea) are more classically associated with RCA occlusion than LCx occlusion.
Transmural infarction specifically suggests occlusion of the primary supplying artery rather than collateral circulation.

supporting.text: In most individuals (approximately 85-90% of the population), the RCA is the dominant artery responsible for perfusion of the posterior descending artery (PDA), which supplies the posterior ventricular septum.

attacks.text: In most individuals (approximately 85-90% of the population), the RCA is the dominant artery responsible for perfusion of the posterior descending artery (PDA), which supplies the posterior ventricular septum.
In the remaining 10-15% of the population, the left circumflex artery (LCx) is dominant and supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA), making RCA occlusion less likely in these cases.
The clinical presentation and imaging findings strongly suggest posterior ventricular septum involvement, which is more commonly associated with RCA occlusion even in LCx-dominant cases.
The patient's symptoms could also be caused by other conditions such as aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism, which would not involve coronary artery occlusion.
The presence of transmural myocardial infarction on imaging is highly specific for coronary artery occlusion, making alternative diagnoses much less likely.

supporting.text: The clinical presentation of substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea is classic for an acute myocardial infarction, and the location of the infarction (posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum) strongly suggests RCA occlusion.

attacks.text: The clinical presentation of substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea is classic for an acute myocardial infarction, and the location of the infarction (posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum) strongly suggests RCA occlusion.
While the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum is typically supplied by the RCA, anatomical variations exist where the left circumflex artery (LCx) may also supply this region.
Anatomical variations where the LCx supplies the posterior ventricular septum are rare, occurring in less than 10% of cases, making RCA occlusion far more likely.
The clinical presentation, while classic for MI, is not pathognomonic and could also be seen in other conditions such as aortic dissection or severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
The presence of imaging-confirmed transmural myocardial infarction effectively rules out non-cardiac causes like GERD or aortic dissection in this context.

supporting.text: Transmural myocardial infarction, as seen in this patient, typically results from complete occlusion of the supplying coronary artery, further supporting the likelihood of RCA occlusion.

attacks.text: Transmural myocardial infarction, as seen in this patient, typically results from complete occlusion of the supplying coronary artery, further supporting the likelihood of RCA occlusion.

The posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum is more commonly supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which can originate from either the RCA or the left circumflex artery (LCx), making RCA occlusion not the only possibility.
In approximately 70-80% of cases (right-dominant circulation), the PDA originates from the RCA, making RCA occlusion statistically more likely in this scenario.
Transmural infarction can also occur due to severe vasospasm or embolism without complete occlusion, which may not be detected on initial imaging.
The presence of classic STEMI symptoms (chest pain, diaphoresis, nausea) and transmural infarction on imaging strongly suggests complete occlusion rather than vasospasm or embolism.

supporting.text: The RCA is the most common site of occlusion leading to inferior wall myocardial infarctions, which often involve the posterior ventricular septum due to its anatomical distribution.

attacks.text: The RCA is the most common site of occlusion leading to inferior wall myocardial infarctions, which often involve the posterior ventricular septum due to its anatomical distribution.

While the RCA is common, the left circumflex artery (LCx) can also supply the posterior ventricular septum and may be the culprit in some cases, particularly in left-dominant or codominant coronary circulation.
Left-dominant circulation occurs in only 10-15% of the population, making RCA occlusion statistically far more likely in this patient demographic.
The patient's symptoms could also suggest multivessel disease or left main occlusion, which would require immediate angiography for confirmation rather than assuming RCA involvement.
Transmural infarction in the posterior septum is highly specific for RCA occlusion (85-90% predictive value) according to current cardiology guidelines.
